detaileddescription.para: LWIP_SUPPORT_CUSTOM_PBUF==1: Custom pbufs behave much like their pbuf type but they are allocated by external code (initialised by calling pbuf_alloced_custom()) and when pbuf_free gives up their last reference, they are freed by calling pbuf_custom->custom_free_function(). Currently, the pbuf_custom code is only needed for one specific configuration of IP_FRAG, unless required by external driver/application code.
indicates this is a custom pbuf: pbuf_free calls pbuf_custom->custom_free_function() when the last reference is released (plus custom PBUF_RAM cannot be trimmed)
indicates this pbuf was received as link-level broadcast
indicates this pbuf was received as link-level multicast
indicates this pbuf is UDP multicast to be looped back
indicates this packet's data should be immediately passed to the application
indicates this pbuf includes a TCP FIN flag
Define this to 0 to prevent freeing ooseq pbufs when the PBUF_POOL is empty
Includes spare room for transport layer header, e.g. UDP header. Use this if you intend to pass the pbuf to functions like udp_send().
Includes spare room for IP header. Use this if you intend to pass the pbuf to functions like raw_send().

Includes spare room for link layer header (ethernet header). Use this if you intend to pass the pbuf to functions like ethernet_output().
PBUF_LINK_HLEN

Includes spare room for additional encapsulation header before ethernet headers (e.g. 802.11). Use this if you intend to pass the pbuf to functions like netif->linkoutput().
PBUF_LINK_ENCAPSULATION_HLEN
Use this for input packets in a netif driver when calling netif->input() in the most common case - ethernet-layer netif driver.
Enumeration of pbuf layers

pbuf data is stored in RAM, used for TX mostly, struct pbuf and its payload are allocated in one piece of contiguous memory (so the first payload byte can be calculated from struct pbuf). pbuf_alloc() allocates PBUF_RAM pbufs as unchained pbufs (although that might change in future versions). This should be used for all OUTGOING packets (TX).
pbuf data is stored in ROM, i.e. struct pbuf and its payload are located in totally different memory areas. Since it points to ROM, payload does not have to be copied when queued for transmission.
pbuf comes from the pbuf pool. Much like PBUF_ROM but payload might change so it has to be duplicated when queued before transmitting, depending on who has a 'ref' to it.

pbuf payload refers to RAM. This one comes from a pool and should be used for RX. Payload can be chained (scatter-gather RX) but like PBUF_RAM, struct pbuf and its payload are allocated in one piece of contiguous memory (so the first payload byte can be calculated from struct pbuf). Don't use this for TX, if the pool becomes empty e.g. because of TCP queuing, you are unable to receive TCP acks!
Enumeration of pbuf types
Allocates a pbuf of the given type (possibly a chain for PBUF_POOL type).
The actual memory allocated for the pbuf is determined by the layer at which the pbuf is allocated and the requested size (from the size parameter).

parameterdescription.para: this parameter decides how and where the pbuf should be allocated as follows:

listitem.para: PBUF_RAM: buffer memory for pbuf is allocated as one large chunk. This includes protocol headers as well.

PBUF_ROM: no buffer memory is allocated for the pbuf, even for protocol headers. Additional headers must be prepended by allocating another pbuf and chain in to the front of the ROM pbuf. It is assumed that the memory used is really similar to ROM in that it is immutable and will not be changed. Memory which is dynamic should generally not be attached to PBUF_ROM pbufs. Use PBUF_REF instead.

PBUF_REF: no buffer memory is allocated for the pbuf, even for protocol headers. It is assumed that the pbuf is only being used in a single thread. If the pbuf gets queued, then pbuf_take should be called to copy the buffer.
PBUF_POOL: the pbuf is allocated as a pbuf chain, with pbufs from the pbuf pool that is allocated during pbuf_init().

simplesect.para: the allocated pbuf. If multiple pbufs where allocated, this is the first pbuf of a pbuf chain.

detaileddescription.para: Concatenate two pbufs (each may be a pbuf chain) and take over the caller's reference of the tail pbuf.

simplesect.para: The caller MAY NOT reference the tail pbuf afterwards. Use pbuf_chain() for that purpose.

detaileddescription.para: Chain two pbufs (or pbuf chains) together.
The caller MUST call pbuf_free(t) once it has stopped using it. Use pbuf_cat() instead if you no longer use t.

h
head pbuf (chain)
t
tail pbuf (chain)
The pbufs MUST belong to the same packet.
MAY NOT be called on a packet queue.
The ->tot_len fields of all pbufs of the head chain are adjusted. The ->next field of the last pbuf of the head chain is adjusted. The ->ref field of the first pbuf of the tail chain is adjusted.
Count number of pbufs in a chain

simplesect.para: the number of pbufs in a chain

detaileddescription.para: Creates a single pbuf out of a queue of pbufs.

simplesect.para: : Either the source pbuf 'p' is freed by this function or the original pbuf 'p' is returned, therefore the caller has to check the result!
a new, single pbuf (p->next is NULL) or the old pbuf if allocation fails

detaileddescription.para: Create PBUF_RAM copies of pbufs.
Used to queue packets on behalf of the lwIP stack, such as ARP based queueing.

simplesect.para: You MUST explicitly use p = pbuf_take(p);
Only one packet is copied, no packet queue!
ERR_OK if pbuf was copied ERR_ARG if one of the pbufs is NULL or p_to is not big enough to hold p_from

memberdef.argsstring: (const struct pbuf *p, void *dataptr, u16_t len, u16_t offset)
memberdef.name: pbuf_copy_partial

detaileddescription.para: Copy (part of) the contents of a packet buffer to an application supplied buffer.

parameterdescription.para: the pbuf from which to copy data
length of data to copy (dataptr must be big enough). No more than buf->tot_len will be copied, irrespective of len
offset into the packet buffer from where to begin copying len bytes

simplesect.para: the number of bytes copied, or 0 on failure

detaileddescription.para: Dechains the first pbuf from its succeeding pbufs in the chain.

Makes p->tot_len field equal to p->len.
p
pbuf to dechain
remainder of the pbuf chain, or NULL if it was de-allocated.
May not be called on a packet queue.
Dereference a pbuf chain or queue and deallocate any no-longer-used pbufs at the head of this chain or queue.
Decrements the pbuf reference count. If it reaches zero, the pbuf is deallocated.

For a pbuf chain, this is repeated for each pbuf in the chain, up to the first pbuf which has a non-zero reference count after decrementing. So, when all reference counts are one, the whole chain is free'd.

simplesect.para: the number of pbufs that were de-allocated from the head of the chain.
MUST NOT be called on a packet queue (Not verified to work yet).
the reference counter of a pbuf equals the number of pointers that refer to the pbuf (or into the pbuf).

internal.para: Assuming existing chains a->b->c with the following reference counts, calling pbuf_free(a) results in:

detaileddescription.para: Get one byte from the specified position in a pbuf WARNING: returns zero for offset >= p->tot_len

parameterdescription.para: offset into p of the byte to return

simplesect.para: byte at an offset into p OR ZERO IF 'offset' >= p->tot_len

detaileddescription.para: Adjusts the payload pointer to hide or reveal headers in the payload.
Adjusts the ->payload pointer so that space for a header (dis)appears in the pbuf payload.
The ->payload, ->tot_len and ->len fields are adjusted.

p
pbuf to change the header size.
header_size_increment
Number of bytes to increment header size which increases the size of the pbuf. New space is on the front. (Using a negative value decreases the header size.) If hdr_size_inc is 0, this function does nothing and returns successful.
PBUF_ROM and PBUF_REF type buffers cannot have their sizes increased, so the call will fail. A check is made that the increase in header size does not move the payload pointer in front of the start of the buffer.
non-zero on failure, zero on success.
Same as pbuf_header but does not check if 'header_size > 0' is allowed. This is used internally only, to allow PBUF_REF for RX.

memberdef.argsstring: (const struct pbuf *p, u16_t offset, const void *s2, u16_t n)
memberdef.name: pbuf_memcmp

detaileddescription.para: Compare pbuf contents at specified offset with memory s2, both of length n

parameterdescription.para: offset into p at which to start comparing

simplesect.para: zero if equal, nonzero otherwise (0xffff if p is too short, diffoffset+1 otherwise)

memberdef.argsstring: (const struct pbuf *p, const void *mem, u16_t mem_len, u16_t start_offset)
memberdef.name: pbuf_memfind

detaileddescription.para: Find occurrence of mem (with length mem_len) in pbuf p, starting at offset start_offset.

parameterdescription.para: pbuf to search, maximum length is 0xFFFE since 0xFFFF is used as return value 'not found'
search for the contents of this buffer
offset into p at which to start searching

simplesect.para: 0xFFFF if substr was not found in p or the index where it was found

detaileddescription.para: Put one byte to the specified position in a pbuf WARNING: silently ignores offset >= p->tot_len

parameterdescription.para: offset into p of the byte to write
byte to write at an offset into p

detaileddescription.para: Shrink a pbuf chain to a desired length.

p
pbuf to shrink.
new_len
desired new length of pbuf chain
Depending on the desired length, the first few pbufs in a chain might be skipped and left unchanged. The new last pbuf in the chain will be resized, and any remaining pbufs will be freed.

simplesect.para: If the pbuf is ROM/REF, only the ->tot_len and ->len fields are adjusted.
May not be called on a packet queue.
Despite its name, pbuf_realloc cannot grow the size of a pbuf (chain).

detaileddescription.para: Increment the reference count of the pbuf.

parameterdescription.para: pbuf to increase reference counter of

detaileddescription.para: Skip a number of bytes at the start of a pbuf

parameterdescription.para: resulting offset in the returned pbuf

simplesect.para: the pbuf in the queue where the offset is

detaileddescription.para: Find occurrence of substr with length substr_len in pbuf p, start at offset start_offset WARNING: in contrast to strstr(), this one does not stop at the first \0 in the pbuf/source string!

parameterdescription.para: pbuf to search, maximum length is 0xFFFE since 0xFFFF is used as return value 'not found'
string to search for in p, maximum length is 0xFFFE

simplesect.para: 0xFFFF if substr was not found in p or the index where it was found

detaileddescription.para: Copy application supplied data into a pbuf. This function can only be used to copy the equivalent of buf->tot_len data.

parameterdescription.para: length of the application supplied data buffer

simplesect.para: ERR_OK if successful, ERR_MEM if the pbuf is not big enough

memberdef.argsstring: (struct pbuf *buf, const void *dataptr, u16_t len, u16_t offset)
memberdef.name: pbuf_take_at

detaileddescription.para: Same as pbuf_take() but puts data at an offset

parameterdescription.para: length of the application supplied data buffer
offset in pbuf where to copy dataptr to

simplesect.para: ERR_OK if successful, ERR_MEM if the pbuf is not big enough

detaileddescription.para: Get one byte from the specified position in a pbuf

parameterdescription.para: offset into p of the byte to return

simplesect.para: byte at an offset into p [0..0xFF] OR negative if 'offset' >= p->tot_len
